Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of the US Ignite Initiative is to break a fundamental deadlock: there is insufficient investment in gigabit applications that can take advantage of advanced network infrastructure because such infrastructure is rare and dispersed. And conversely, there is a lack of broad availability of advanced broadband infrastructure for open experimentation and innovation because there are few advanced applications and services to justify it. US Ignite applications are focused on national priority areas of advanced manufacturing, clean energy and transportation, cyber learning, health IT, and public safety/emergency preparedness. Many of the applications under development in this program build on NSF-funded advanced networking and computational infrastructure developed as part of the NSF GENI program. All of the projects demonstrate the value of advanced networking. This project supports the 3rd annual US Ignite Application Summit, an event that will demonstrate the next generation applications currently being developed, educate a broad community on the potential for next-generation application capabilities and recruit cities and individuals for the next round of application development.

The Applications Summit is being held March 24-25, 2015 at George Washington University's Marvin Center in Washington, DC and the Hilton Crystal City Hotel in Arlington, VA. Co-location with the GENI Engineering Conference (GEC 22) and meetings of the Open Grid Forum (OGF) and Global Lambda Integrated Facility (GLIF) will maximize the potential for advancing technology, education, and outreach. This project supports academic and student participation in the Summit, along with the costs of hosting the event and broadly disseminating its results throughout the advanced networking research and gigabit application development communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
US Ignite hosted the 2015 Application Summit, co-located with the 23rd GENI Engineering Conference (GEC) and nicknamed SmartFuture 2015, on March June 24 to 25, 2015 in Arlington, Virginia.   During the event, fully-titled Beyond Today’s Internet: Experiencing a Smart Future, attendees experienced first-hand demos of next-generation applications run on this new type of software-defined, deeply-programmable gigabit network. Keynote speakers, tech presenters, and workshops led by visionaries in the field and community leaders highlighted recent case studies, success stories, and best practices in creating next-generation technology initiatives. 

The event convened over 350 participants, and it is one of the only events to showcase dozens of live demonstrations of advanced networking public benefit applications. It brought together the developers, technologists, corporate labs and academic researchers interested in the unlimited potential of advanced technologies like symmetric gigabit, software defined networking (SDN) and local cloud with the organizations, municipalities, and government leaders who want to leverage these networks to address challenges faced in education, healthcare, transportation and more, yielding economic development and positive social outcomes.

The event’s purpose was two-fold: education and community building.  The event brought together developers, industry, communities, government, foundations and universities working with SDN, cloud computing, and gigabit networks. US Ignite and GENI, with the help of our partners at the National Science Foundation and Mozilla Foundation, showcased new next-generation applications running on deeply programmable cyberinfrastructure that transcends the current Internet and has the potential to completely transform how we live, work, learn, and play..

The diverse group heard from communities with deployed advanced networks and gave participants a “first” look at the transformative power of next-generation technologies. These “firsts” were “things” that had not previously been demonstrated or seen before, such as:

  • 4K gigabit-enabled digital microscopy, whereby Summit attendees could see a live 4K image of a specimen under a microscope in Los Angeles and manipulate that microscope from the Summit location in Washington, DC;
  • A connected-vehicle demonstration showing real-time emergency responders in Madison, Wisconsin simultaneously using drone camera footage, on-board vehicle cameras, and remote sensing devices to accelerate the response to a simulated incident; and
  • A real-time programming simulator called the “Mars Rover,” a collaborative interactive environment that teaches math and programming in a fun and rewarding 3D gaming experience.
  • UT Dallas, SAP America, Hasso-Plattner Institute, US Ignite, and University of Victoria   researchers demonstrate distributed collaborative scientific visualization system and distributed aerosol pollution viewer

The highlights were the 30 application demonstrations. To recognize the greatest achievements, US Ignite presented the following Summit awards:

1.         Best Use of a Gigabit: Multipoint Connected Collaboration, free, open source high definition, high fidelity, point-to-point video conferencing solution over gigabit networks using commodity PC and Mac hardware -
